comments.commentBody:
@Meredith and @Karen

I dread Election 2016, especially if the only viable choice turns out to be Hillary Clinton. I really don't want to vote for her for the reasons Karen states here, in addition to the reasons that Roger Cohen and Timothy Egan bring up in their op-eds today. Hillary Clinton is hardly the person we should entrust with the job of steering our nation on the right social ethics track. Hardly.

And you have to ask (and be moderately intelligent enough to know to ask):  if people really just wanted to live off welfare and not work, how come under Clinton (when there were jobs regardless of how said jobs were created) we had low low unemployment?  Why, when there are ample jobs, do people take them if they don't want to work?  Answer:  that's easy.

You are assuming "all Republicans are rich", which is a bit contradictory to the other position that "all Republicans are ignorant, red-neck hicks from the South and Midwest".

You can't have it both ways. A lot of people, including plenty of blue-staters -- otherwise liberal on most social issues -- see the abuse of the food stamp and welfare system AND SSDI, by ... yes .... people who are lazy and do not want to work.

That does not mean nobody deserves help, or that food stamps should be done away with. Not at all. It means the programs need stricter controls and penalties, and that we need to find out why the food stamp program increased by 100% under Obama, and did not return anywhere near normal levels as the economy recovered.

NOTE: if Republicans were really only 1%, they would get about as many votes as the Green Party or the American Communist Party -- and they would not be running the House of Representatives.

Concerned Citizen:

'Conservatives are not necessarily stupid, but most stupid people are conservatives." - John Stuart Mill

Much the same applies, I think, to wealth and Republicans. Republicans are not necessarily wealthy, but most wealthy people are Republican.

It is interesting to watch the Republicans and Conservatives tell us that people prefer food stamps, unemployment insurance, Medicaid, and home foreclosures to work. This from the people who hide their money offshore, move their profits offshore, move the jobs offshore, and although they are in the One Percent, is not the One Percent that serves in the Armed Forces.

We've gone from a country where we went to the moon in ten years to one where college graduates are still living with their parents ten years after graduating, and the bridges are collapsing around us.

When each generation has fewer opportunities as a society than their predecessors, it is time to consider that something is seriously wrong.
Those who wish to do good have failed to present arguments persuasive enough to convince voters to throw the bums out. More bluntly stated: evil's masquerade as prudence has been successful.

I hate having to have a phone with me because it's cumbersome to have to have it in my hand or in some inconvenient pocket. I prefer to have a watch and am looking forward to the day when the essential phone functions (like voice, time, calendar, appointments etc. are on my wrist.
Touchscreen alone is not practical. It has to partner with voice recognition so that you can have your attention on something else, like driving while you speak, and can look at it while cycling or swimming when you don't have pockets.
An occasional interface with a computer/wireless network is essential but should not need to be continuous to perform its essential functions.
Bring on the smartwatch and the first company that is able to do this well will have me as a customer. Also I want to be able to defeat the GPS feature. I like to be alone sometimes.
Voting out the bums without changing the system just results in the election of new bums and increased cynicism. Get the money out of politics and the bums problem will take care of itself.

Kant, it really is a much stickier wicket than your macro view of the investor class.  My wife's pension from teaching school for 35 years and my disbursement from an IRA converted from 401 K is also dependent upon the health of the markets.  The issue is curbing abuse of the system by the whining "makers" while rewarding the efforts of the working class during their working years.
50% of all investment in the stock market belongs to 1% of Americans.

What waste? As long as the "investor" class and their offshore money hoards are doing fine, how does it matter that the rest of the country may be crumbling? The unemployment crisis should have spurred a robust "Jobs" bill to be passed long long ago. But it did not. It is amazing how beholden our law makers have become to their rich patrons. They will not act to reduce the misery and suffering of the "masses." But, if the stock market plunges putting the investor class at risk, they will immediately spring to action passing laws to help it recover. What a joke!

We really need to get money out of politics or risk continued economic policy domination by the rich and the corporations they own! "Vote the bums out" and wrest control of the government at all levels in 2014 is the only way out of the 5-year jobs crisis.

Having spent nearly twenty years living in the South and directing a history museum that interpreted the Civil War, I encountered this sort of deflective argument frequently. Grant was a butcher; Sherman was crazy; Lincoln was a totalitarian monster; Lee was a saint; slaves were happy, and willingly fought to help the South; the war was fought over states' rights (or maybe tariffs!), not slavery ; etc.; etc.; etc. What really happened is far more complex--often threatening to closely held beliefs about one's personal heritage and never well-served by Lost Cause claptrap. The Civil War sesquicentennial provides an opportunity to exchange wishful historical thinking and myth for a deeper, more nuanced understanding of events 150 years ago that still shape American society.

Criticize President Obama for not acting in knee-jerk fashion to take a huge risk in bombing a middle eastern country?  Some may wish for the instant black/white, yes/no answer as to whether to embark on the military mission in Syria.  Rather, the President has given us a gift...the opportunity to debate, weigh the arguments, and assess not just what to do, or not to do, but why.  Mr. Egan has spelled out some very good reasons to cast doubt on a military mission in Syria, and why we should think carefully BEFORE the bombing begins.  Those who foolishly supported the previous wars have their heads in the sands, hiding from their knee-jerk judgments.   I support a President who takes time for due diligence, and asks Congress and the American people to do the same.

That's because George Bush's problems could not be blamed on his predecessor. W inherited a surplus from the Clinton administration and proceeded to blow through it with abandon. Lowering taxes on the wealthy while initiating two wars was idiocy. It made the banking crisis that much harder to deal with.

And, to the subject of this article and your weak objection, how could W blame his predecessor for his not keeping us safe on 9/11; allowing Wall St. to "get drunk" as he called it; choosing to lie to the world about WMDs; or spectacularly mismanaging the Iraq invasion and occupation?

The reason W never blamed his predecessor was because the blame belonged to him and no one else.

"I cannot recall a single instance when George Bush blamed his numerous problems on his predecessor."
... look a little harder, G.W. Bush was constantly blaming his predecessors, for the economy, North Korea, and especially he never took responsibility for 9/11.

The Times' policy of not printing unhinged abuse, in my view a sound one, seems in the present case not to apply to its own columnists. Nevertheless I will adhere to it by merely noting that Mr. Egan's rant seems to have only one point to make. This is that the current president's inability to act in circumstances where he said he would act, unless the responsibility is shifted to the whole world, is all the fault of George W. Bush, with a hat tip to Donald Rumsfeld. I cannot recall a single instance when George Bush blamed his numerous problems on his predecessor.
As to Mr. Bush's paintings of his feet in the bathtub, I find them rather charming. Others may not. But surely we can agree that they have nothing to say about what is to be done in Syria.
It is high time we all did. Unfortunately, the One Percent isn't done making sure things get a lot worse.

Len Charlap, but that's none of our businesses. Mc Donald's produces something and offers certain wages. If people don't like it, they can go and apply elsewhere, and also open their own businesses. Who are we (who, let's assume, don't employ people) to decide about their productivity and salaries?
Also, Mc Donald's changed its productivity or the workers'?

If you want it to stop, open your own food chain and pay a salary you consider fair. Or convince consumers to stop going to Mc Donald's until they do.

The market speaks with purchase decisions. We all want higher salaries, fair conditions, etc., but keep purchasing iPhones, eating at fast food chains, etc.

Chris Winter,

Again, people talk about Mc Donald's as if it was using slave labor which can't decide freely where to go. I'm not saying that these jobs are amazing. Of course not. I'm only saying that people are free to go elsewhere and those who criticize and have strong opinions about certain companies' finances, should prove it by doing it themselves.
If people still choose to work at Mc Donald's is because, sadly, there are no better options for them. And that's the issue to me.
Did anyone understand this?  I didn't.

@ME and others.

For a start you might try reading up on the economic crisis. This is all covered in "To Big To Fail: by Andrew Ross Sorkin." Then read the Angelides Commission report on "The Financial Crisis," and you can see documentation of what these banks did, what the Fed and Treasury did, and how it all used the crisis.

Read Hank Paulso's book, " On The Brink." In it he describes just how close the total economic system came to a complete freeze, and he is a conservative.

In today's MarketWatch.com is an article: "By Rex Nutting:
Why is GDP stuck at 2%? Low wages, fiscal drag
Commentary: Doing the math on our sub-par economy"

While there are some 600 comments to the Krugman post, 90% of them are opinions, some may contain fats, but not with verification. Your comment (ME) is an example why the economy is still where it is, lots of opinions, and very few facts, so when the politicians are looking for a fix, they listen to popular opinion as that is what the voter tell them they want.

Worse yet, there is a faction mostly GOP, that makes it a policy to deny the facts of the economic crisis, leading to even more failures to bring the economy back to where we would like to see it. Just because some Wall Street banks engaged in financial manipulations, does not make it correct policy to make all banks the whipping boys.

We need to remember Lehman fell after Bear Sterns was rescued by a loan from the Fed, sold to J.P. Morgan Chase preventing a total collapse of the system. Lehman Brothers was nex in the sights of the funds that had shorted them.They had leveraged their debt as high as 10:1 and had to cover more debt than they were worth every day in the repo market.

The administration was opposed to bailouts, they tried to get a buyer for Lehman, but no one would pay enough for the company, it was allowed to go bankrupt. That set off a chain of events which put the next weaker brokerages in the sights of the vultures. Merrill Lynch was next to be targeted. What these companies all had in common was their underwriting of Collateralized Debt Obligations and other derivatives. Citibank was another bank that had billions in leveraged debt.

Then following the Black-Sholles model, they all tried to sell the CDOs they held. They got the bond rating companies to rate them investment grade, the bottom feel out. They all needed liquidity, they had none. The credit market froze, companies could not sell their commercial paper. Funds and institutions that had those "Investment vehicles" could not sell them.

H.M. Paulson convinced Bush to go to congress and get it to allow the Fed to bring the investment banks under its purview. Without that the crisis would have been far worse than any previously. It was not as much help as it could have been, but it saved us then.
Right on!
Make no mistake Bushs' failures were real!!
Are you saying that you own up to being a Bush supporter and all that he stood for?

I'm starting to understand how you think, Mike. The Congressional Budget Office reported a budget surplus between the years 1998 and 2000, the last three years of Clinton's presidency. So if inheriting a budget surplus counts for you as inheriting "an economic disaster,' . . . uh, . . . right.

President Clinton also left office with the highest end-of-office approval rating of any U.S. President since World War II -- better than Ronald Reagan (FYI read "The Acting President" (1989) by Schieffer and Gates, if you want to know how befuddled he was) -- in spite of that truly ridiculous, pointless, country-harming impeachment (and in spite of all that other wasted money and mud-slinging by Ken Starr -- they just didn't quit trying, did they?). You say Bush didn't complain about his predecessor, but the record shows that relative to other end-of-term national opinions, Bush had little to complain about . . .

. . . especially that budget surplus -- did I mention that?

Hard to know where to start here. Egan slams W for refusing to insert himself into this debate, but only after mocking Rumsfeld for doing so. He condemns Republicans who will vote against the resolution to attack Syria as acting out of hate for Obama, but seems unconcerned about the motivation of Democrats who will also vote against the President. Throughout this piece, Egan descends into puerile insults - Grandmother Appreciation Day? Rubber room? Fantasy football advice?
But the most objectionable aspect of this piece is his refusal evaluate Obama on his own terms. Excusing a 2nd term president's incompetence by blaming it on his predecessor is pathetic. One could just as easily argue that all of the decisions Bush had to make were a product of his predecessor's derelictions. After all, Bush had only been in the WH for 8 months prior to 9/11. For 8 years Clinton had allowed al Qaeda to emerge as a threat, the Taliban to solidify power in Afghanistan, and Hussein to remain unscathed in Iraq. In other words, one could argue, if one were so inclined, that W's failures (if indeed one believes they were failures) were a result of Clinton's legacy.
At any rate, pretty much everything Egan says could be applied in reverse - in other words, if Reps who supported war in Iraq are hypocrites for opposing it now in Syria, what does that say about Dems who opposed the former but support the latter?
It would be gratifying to see liberals "own" their president, the good and the bad.

I've heard of vans like this being used in rural areas of the U.S., I think out west. I saw a documentary about rural health care and remember this coming up. I think the van rotated among several different small towns, though, not staying within one of them.

The more I think of it, I'd like to see this option pursued. With electronic data, it can be easily facilitated. A triage person would assign cases (perhaps a "real" emergency like cardiac) would be brought immediately to hospital, but most others would be served at home in a reasonable time. Computers and specialist teams would be hooked up thru the hospital computers for testing or other services delivered at home. Patients could relax, knowing services will come to them, and there is less expense than needing full ER services for many more simple cases.

Of course, Simonts excellent question: "One has to wonder: if this is possible and feasible (and fully reimbursed by insurance) in Germany why is it not possible in our country?" is one we ask about many situations, including single payer. And we know the answer.

A brilliant idea. Why couldn't we come up with it,  when we've come up with so many things here. Probably because there's no money in it, so no one is really interested or motivated. The same is true for our public education. If , and when we really value and want something in this country, we have the wherewithal to get it done.

In parts of Germany, there is a roving medical van with MD available at all times on nights and weekends. The van drives around the town doing sick calls and also attending to general emergencies. Its scheduled on rotation, like being "on call" and will take the patient to the hospital if necessary, just like an ambulance. They also have some medications on board, when needed. Therefore there is little need for an emergency room at all. You just call and they come to you. It is convenient, more personal, less wasteful and less expensive.

Unfortunately, the "investor" class is not just the Mitt Romneys of the world. Very humble, working-class people depend on investments to fund their children's college education and their own retirement accounts and pensions. A stick market plunge would only add to their misery, while not hurting enough the people I think you are referring to.
Just as Obama would be wise to steer clear of Syria. Too bad Monty Python's not still around: Here, don't mind the killer ophthalmologist!

I don't entirely agree.

First off, the main point is to stop wanton interference by the U.S. in other countries' problems. No matter the use of chemical weapons or slaughter of their own citizens (by the way, both of which we supported and actually aided when Saddam Hussein was our anti-Iranian ally), it is not our right to attack on our own. There are established international mechanisms, the International Criminal Court without war and the U.N. Security Council with war. Neither has been tried by Obama, and if neither succeeds here, our responsibility is non-existent.

Noting that the U.S. would be embarrassed to appeal to the ICC, which it has refused to join for fear that Americans who committed war crimes might be held responsible (and why not?), that is a lousy excuse for not doing it.

Secondly, I see no reason why George W. Bush should have an opinion about current policy. Staying out of it is the right thing for him to do. If only he'd been as wise (pardon my applying the word to him) when he was president--or before he chose to run!
After reading this article, I'm kinda jealous of Germany. A sound economy when the rest of the world was floundering; cautious foreign policy. Good for them. Other countries should take notice.

Yes, German silence on this issue is the silence of learned wisdom.  Much as one finds it distasteful to agree with Russia's Mr. Putin, as well, he also seems to have it right on this one. Air attacks on those poison gas facilities would merely risk setting the gas free in the air to kill more innocent civilians. It furthermore would open those facilities to attacks by religious fanatics, who would then use the stolen cannisters of gas in terrorist activities or sell them on the black market to others. Mr. Obama is far less wise than we once were led to believe.

"But remain strong for what? The United States wants Germany to assume a global role commensurate with its power."

This is thinking that has gotten the US into so much trouble.

"Remain strong for what?" This implies strength must be used or it is wasted, and it must be used assertively against other nations. That is exactly what Germany did to get itself into nightmare, and exactly what it rejects. It is right to do so, and that is a lesson we must learn. Cohen ought to know better.

"The US wants Germany to assume a global role?" No, the US does not want any such thing. The US wants Germany to do exactly as the US tells it to do. The US wants to control Germany's potential power, and the US wants to use that as part of all its other power. You don't think so? Consider if Germany assumed a role commensurate with its power and then DISAGREED with the US on something. Then nasty stuff would hit the fan.

This article really means Germany ought to spend its money and lend its forces to us to do what we tell them to do. Today, it is to attack Syria. Not so long ago, it was to render prisoners to Syria via Germany. Soon, it may be to fight the rebels that the US now supports. Germany has no interest in doing that. I don't have to wonder why.

I do wonder why we keep doing these things. Why don't we act more as a merchant state, and less as an aggressive rogue state?

"Pro-life" reserves its emotional arguments, its disturbing videos and giant signs, for late-term abortions. In cases like this, very early abortions conducted quickly, quietly, and safely, it conjures up convoluted legal strategies to get around the impulse of doctors toward maximum safety, care, and kindness for their patients. "Pro-life" wants those patients stymied, confused, frustrated, and frightened. It even wants them exposed to unnecessarily high doses of medication, lest they get off too easily.

This case, so carefully and cleverly planned, highlights the true "pro-life" goal of trapping people into unhappy outcomes of forced, unnatural legal conundrums. The "pro-life" movement is trying to eliminate, step by step, the autonomy of women and their ability to decide when and whether to bring children into the world. The movement is also working to guarantee stressed, inadequate parenting, unwanted or orphaned children, and a heightened misery index for everyone touched by its highly organized machinations.

Oklahoma Judge Donald L. Worthington, quoted in the article, said it well: these efforts on the part of pro-life activists "can serve no purpose other than to prevent women from obtaining abortions and to punish and discriminate against those women who do."

Abortion is never a deliberate act of hatred and cruelty. But what these people are doing certainly looks like just that.

I haven't seen Krugman promote austerity, but do I remember correctly that he promoted the Clinton surpluses?

And the Clinton surpluses were bad, Bad, BAD..not good. It would have tanked the economy just as austerity has performed in Europe except for one thing--as Clinton amassed surpluses, the private sector aggregate responded by amassing record levels of debt - eg housing debt. Households and businesses went into the red when the US treasury moved into the black. And lest we forget, that housing debt, otherwise known as the housing bubble, blew a hole in the economy we have yet to recover from.
That's because economists like Rogoff et al promise that spending cuts will get the economy back on the right track! And Rogoff's paper was flawed anyway.

Good question. When something doesn't appear to make sense, you have to keep looking and you'll find an explanation. Logic tells you that Summers and the economists and politicians wanted things to get better. They wanted to fix roads and educate children -- they just disagreed on how to implement. But since it really is textbook economics, then you have to ask yourself if those powers that be actually did want things to get better. Maybe they don't want your kid to get an education unless you're rich enough to pay for private school. Last time we had really good public education all the way to the top, the younger generation rebelled, rejecting authority and consumerism. We can't have that, again.

No, the answers to "What do we do to fix this?" were too obvious. The fact that Republicans and the economists who support them took a different road en masse tells you that they didn't want things fixed, that poor people are easier to manipulate, that in hard times big money can buy up everything, and that a little hardship on the many is good for the bank accounts of the few.

What bothers me is: Why did so many economists (Dr Krugman excepted) ignore "textbook economics" and promote austerity instead? How did dunderheads like Larry Summers who ignore their own textbooks make it to the top levels of government, academia, and the private sector? My guess is that, even under the best of circumstances, many people -- including economists -- and most Tea Partiers -- ignore science, and choose instead to believe whatever is expedient...whatever they want to believe. This is the common thread that runs through Lysenkoism, climate change denial, austerity economics, and Creationism. Sad that Economics remains so susceptible, even at the highest levels: the "dismal science" indeed. More so than in other fields, it seems that being loudmouth like Larry counts for more than being perceptive like Paul.

Agree Barbara, and thanks from this "old" Vietnam Vet who now works with Vets from Mr. Bush's misbegotten wars that, through ignorance and arrogance, unleashed centuries of Arab/Persian tribal
conflicts. Mr. Egan is a light in the wilderness, unless you believe that all of this is somehow President Obama's doing, and that he should just do--what ?
Personally I like the notion of a cyberattack on
Syria's government and military tech capability, as suggested by Prof J. Yoder in an editorial in Seattle Times on Sept. 5...somehow our military force response to every world problem needs to be rethought and redirected.
Absolutely. Well said.

I don't see how anyone could have said this better.    I also agree with Warren Swill in every detail, except that I think "ashamed" is too gentle a word.  I can't of any word, for that matter, that can sum up the feelings we should have about a president who was elected by one Supreme Court vote and yet decided he had an absolute mandate to lie boldfaced to the American people, destroy the lives of so many hundreds of thousands of people, and whose "legacy" is the disaster as described above.  Thank you, Mr Egan, for finally articulating the reality of this tragic situation.

What time did he have for that, to cast aspersion on  Bush and Chaney, the country was near economic collapse when president Obama came into office. What we have is a group of conservatives that is so consumed by hatred and fueled by jealousy of president Obama they cannot see straight.   They wanted Obama to come to congress.  voting no and embarrassing Obama means more to them than stopping  the mass killings in Syria.

In regard to WW II, I'd like to see Dr. K. discuss the combined effect of rationing, pent up demand, and the post-war satisfaction of that demand; by  industry that switched from producing war materiel to consumer goods without much inflation.

Let's not forget another aftermath of WW II: the thousands of returning GIs whose "pent-up demand" was accompanied by government-provided higher education in the form of the GI Bill.

That was an investment that added to the productivity and innovation that contributed to widespread prosperity and growth of the middle class in the 50s, 60s, and 70s.
Many believe that Hoover and Roosevelt's spending spree and economic intervention simply dragged out the depression. I certainly don't believe that WWII was good economics.

The history of the Great Depression and WW II underscores Paul Krugman's point. As with the recent stimulus, New Deal spending, while helpful, was inadequate to the task of returning the economy to full employment. Yet the massive, federal deficit spending in the runup to, and execution of the second world war finally put the nail in the coffin of the Great Depression.

Tragically, it seems that it would take another existential crisis akin to a world war to induce the American political system to enact the type of stimulus program Dr. Krugman recommends.

Clearly, though, with so many Americans still unemployed and underemployed, the very last thing we should be doing now is enacting more austerity measures, such as the sequester!

A dual economy exists. A casino for the rich which produces no goods or services. The profits are untaxable or taxed a preferentially low rate. Cataspheric losses are repaid at taxpayer expense. The millionaires who played in this casino economy were playing with other people’s money. Thus the taxpayer bailout. We could have exacted a price for this government insurance. Secondary assets, credit default swaps should have been dissolved and treated as gambling losses of no economic consequence. But these people owned the government and it did not happen and they are playing the same games. They are too big to fail or brake up or prosecute. We need a DOJ with guts.

Agreed, moving ahead slowly is better than standing still or going backwards; yet the reality is that America is governed by two right wing parties. The Democrats the other right wing party, better than the GOP, sometimes, just sometimes, tries to make the lives of the working population safer and more secure but is not pro union, pro living wage and has done nothing to prevent the deindustrialized America and exportation of millions of jobs, making the domestic worker to compete in a race to the bottom with foreign workers. The fact is that the majority of working people are not represented by either party and we need a 3 party system. Republicans, Democrats and Independents who may caucus or vote with the Democrats or not. That will break the Teaparty strangle hold and move the Democrats to the left.
Gee, maybe we could restrict that financial marker debt, huh? After all, it caused the problem. No, guess not.
Yes.

The final sentence should read, "But, by any objective standard, U.S. economic policy before Lehman was an astonishing, horrifying failure."

In that,

1. Since the mid-1970s the U.S. system (combined household, corporate, and government) debt/income ratio has risen relentlessly, thus creating a "normal" (the experience of recent decades) that is unnatural (less stable and more unsustainable), enabled mainly by the reserve currency status of the U.S. dollar, which status is being eroded by the scale of the debt/income imbalance.

2. The "normal" ahead of the Great Recession featured tax and regulatory policies that has given the U.S. the most skewed income distribution of any developed economy. The extreme share of income going to households in the top few percentiles in the past 15 years is effectively a tax on all the rest.

Professor K’s prescription of a larger debt-funded stimulus (16+% of GDP in 2009)translates to the proposition that the ratio of market debt plus unfunded liabilites/income can be on an ever upward path because there is no willpower in the U.S. to reduce that ratio in “good times” and thereby stabilize the ratio over secular time frames. Keynesianism can work in the very long-run only with that collective self-discipline. Is current policy actually imposing that discipline?

Or, are we really going to grow our way out of financial market debt plus unfunded liabilities which total at least $120,000,000,000,000 and equal 7-8 times annual U.S. GDP?
Germany invests in its citizens rather than exploits them: health insurance and health care, public education, professional and technical education, job retraining, etc.

Do you ever read Krugman's blog? He's refuted exactly what you've written countless times. No wonder he keeps having to repeat himself-no matter what the evidence actually says, you'll keep repeating your talking points.

To answer your question re: one pocket to another - yes. Because your right pocket isn't spending money, and it does no good to the economy in your pocket. But the left pocket spends the money which gets it into circulation where others spend it on something else, etc.

It is called an economy. Using your pocket theory of money, the economy should be the same size in 2013 AD as it was in 1013 AD, which clearly isn't the case.

The US economy grew faster A.D. 1840-1860, when banks printed their own money and the cabinet had about six departments, than it has grown in any 20-year period since. So the problem goes back 150 years, not 5, as Libertarians and Tea Partiers realize. Producers add value. Bureaucrats subtract it.

In Europe, the countries that actually reduced spending since A.D. 2008 are doing pretty well; the countries that suffered spending-growth slowdowns and called it austerity, not so much.

If deficits are good, why did the economy stumble as soon as Ms. Pelosi ballooned Mr. Hastert's deficits? If the stimulus helped where it was spent, but hurt where it was taxed from or borrowed from or inflated from, how can it have done any good whatsoever overall--do I get rich by moving money from one pocket to another? It rented Ohio with Chinese money.

In about 10 years demographics will balloon the deficit. You say we need more deficit now.. Hogwash, but if granted, when do we start doing something about the deficit during this window of opportunity? When a triple stimulus fails, doing no overall good whatsoever, will you demand an octuple stimulus, or repent of the sins of liberalism and follow King Jesus the libertarian?
